Graphical abstract The development of high-performance copper (Cu)-based catalysts is critical to achieve the industrial hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to methyl glycolate (MG). To understand the effect of Cu valence state on MG formation, a theoretical study was performed over Cu+-perfect, Cu+-defective, Cu0, and Cu0/Cu+ catalysts by density-functional theory calculations. Calculations showed that the rate-limiting step (RLS) on the Cu+-perfect catalyst was H2 dissociation, whereas CH3OOCCHOH hydrogenation becomes the RLS for the Cu+-defective catalyst. For Cu0 and Cu0/Cu+, DMO dissociation was the RLS. Compared with other three catalysts, Cu0/Cu+ bicomponent catalyst needed to overcome the lowest barrier (168.6 kJ/mol), which is suggested to be an optimal catalyst for selective DMO hydrogenation. The remarkable catalyst efficiency was ascribed to the synergistic effect between the Cu0 and Cu+ sites. The calculation results indicated that Cu0 was beneficial to the dissociation of H2 and was primarily responsible for the hydrogenation (CH3OOCCO-MG), whereas Cu+ was beneficial to DMO dissociation. Besides, Cu+ stabilized intermediates. In summary, we have found that the adsorption energy of CH3OOCCO+H can be considered as the catalyst performance descriptor through the calculation results. Because Cu0/Cu+ agreed with the index of moderate adsorption energy, Cu0/Cu+ presented the best catalytic performance. Keywords Methyl glycolate (MG) Dimethyl oxalate (DMO) Cu catalyst Valence state Descriptor 1 Introduction Methyl glycolate (MG) is a high economic value fine-chemical product [1,2]. It can serve as an excellent solvent or as an important chemical intermediate. Furthermore, its downstream products branch is broad, and includes ethylene glycol, methyl malonate, and glycolic acid, which are applied extensively in the chemical industry, in medicine, and in many other areas [2,3]. Among various synthesis methods, dimethyl oxalate (DMO) hydrogenation reduction to MG has gained attention because of its high atomic utilization and its environmentally friendly process [4]. By controlling the degree of DMO hydrogenation, different products could be obtained in the order of MG, ethylene glycol (EG), and ethanol (EtOH) [1,2,5]. The key to the DMO hydrogenation reaction is to control the degree of hydrogenation by designing a suitable catalyst to achieve an ideal catalytic result. Ag-based catalysts have been studied extensively because of their good catalytic performance. Specifically, silver is usually dispersed in MCM-41 [6], carbon nanotubes [7], silica [8] or activated carbon [5]. Because of cost considerations, studies on Cu-based catalysts have increased. Researchers have found that Cu-based catalysts can achieve the same catalytic effect by adjusting the preparation method. Copper is typically dispersed in hydroxyapatite [1], silica [2,4], and activated carbon [9]. Based on the cost, activity, and other aspects, increased research has focused on the preparation of effective and stable Cu-based catalysts. However, to date, no agreement has been reached on the active sites for the DMO hydrogenation reaction in the Cu catalyst system. San et al. pointed out that the active center of the ester-hydrogenation reaction was single Cu0 sites. San et al. [10] found that Cu/H-MOR and Cu/HZSM-5 had no activity for ester hydrogenation; copper species that were supported on H-zeolite could not be reduced to zero valence, owing to the strong interaction force between the copper species and the H-zeolite. In contrast, Cu/ZnO, which was easy to reduce, displayed a high reactive activity. Kong et al. [11] prepared Raney Cu catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of DMO and Cu0 is the single active site. Differently, Yuan et al. proposed that the catalytic performance of Cu/SiO2 improved significantly by the increase of Cu+ surface concentration, which indicates that Cu+ is the main active center [12–14]. Recently, researchers have indicated that a strong synergistic effect exists between Cu0 and Cu+ in DMO hydrogenation, which is the complex active center of the reaction [1,2,4,9,15–17]. Wang et al. revealed the balancing effect of two types of active Cu species, and demonstrated that Cu0 facilitates the H2 dissociation, whereas Cu+ can stabilize the methoxy and acyl species. In addition, Cu+ can serve as electrophilic or Lewis acid sites to polarize the CO bond by oxygen lone pair electrons [4,16]. Chen et al. [18] pointed out that Cu+ can activate DMO. Gong et al. reported that Cu+ species promote intermediate conversion and facilitate the deep hydrogenation product [19]. Chang et al. stated that the Cu0/Cu+ interface can change the product distribution, mediate CH3OH selectivity effectively, and produce possible reaction channels that are not seen in conventional catalysts [20,21]. LaGrow visualized the Cu/Cu2O interface with environmental scanning transmission electron microscopy [22]. Song et al. [23] confirmed that a coordination of the composition between the stoichiometric oxide and the metal would be a valid way to exploit a suitable hydrogenation catalyst. To resolve the argument above, to clarify the roles of the Cu0 and Cu+ species on MG formation, and to control the degree of hydrogenation with a high MG selectivity, we constructed a Cu0/Cu+ complex model, compared the reaction mechanism and the reaction process with that in Cu0 and Cu+ [24], and revealed the mechanism of generating MG over Cu catalysts. These results provide guidance for rational catalyst design from a theoretical study. 2 Computational details 2.1 Computational methods All DFT calculations were conducted by using the Dmol3 module in the Materials Studio 5.5 package [25]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and the exchange-correlation functional Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) were applied [26,27]. The double numerical basis set with polarization functions (DNP) was used [28]. The effective core potential (ECP) was used to depict the interaction between the atomic cores and electrons for metal atoms [28]. Other atoms were handled with an all-electron basis set. Brillouin zone sampling was carried out by using (4 × 4 × 1) Monkhorst-Pack grids. A complete linear synchronous transit/quadratic synchronous transit (LST/QST) was used to search for the reaction transition states (TS) [29]. The vibrational frequency was computed to confirm the TS structures. A Hirschfeld charge analysis method was used to calculate the charge transfers [30]. The convergence criteria of energy, maximum force, and displacement were set to 2 × 10−5 hartree, 0.004/Å, and 5 × 10-3 Å, respectively. The self-consistent field (SCF) density convergence was set to 1.0 × 10−5 hartree and the Methfessel-Paxton smearing was 0.005 hartree. 2.2 Computational models The Cu0, Cu+-perfect, and Cu0/Cu+ complex model were used to represent different valence states of the Cu catalysts. The low index (111) of Cu and Cu2O was dominant, so surface (111) was selected in this study [31,32]. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the Cu0 was modeled by using three-layer p(4 × 4) super cells, in which the top layer was relaxed during the optimization, whereas the bottom two layers were kept frozen in the optimized bulk positions [33]. The Cu0 surface included four adsorption sites: top, bridge, Fcc, and Hcp. As presented in Fig. 1b, the Cu+-perfect was modeled by using the p(2 × 2) super cells with two trilayer-thick Cu2O(111), in which the bottom trilayer was kept fixed at the optimized bulk positions. The Cu+-perfect surface included four adsorption sites: Cucus, Cucsa, Osuf, and Osub. Cucus, and Cucsa sites were coordination unsaturated Cu and saturated Cu atoms, respectively. Osuf and Osub sites were the surface O and subsurface O atoms, respectively. Schulz et al. proposed that adsorbed atomic hydrogen is considered to cover the empty coordinate sites of the surface cations [34], which shows that in hydrogen-rich cases, the Cu2O surface contains oxygen-vacancies [35]. Previous extensive research [36–38] has confirmed that defects exist on the surface of the metal oxide in a practical situation, and the oxygen-vacancies are interrelated closely with the surface properties. As a result, as shown in Fig. 1c, Cu+-defective was constructed by removing a single surface oxygen atom to consider the possible circumstances. A four-layer Cu(111) surface with a p(4 × 6) super cell was used for the Cu0/Cu+ complex model (Fig. 1d). The top two layers were relaxed, whereas the bottom two layer were kept frozen, and four O atoms were deposited on the surface on the basis of a Cu2O(111) surface structure, followed by structural optimization to obtain the Cu0/Cu+ complex model [35,39,40], which is similar to previous research [41,42]. The surface of the Cu0/Cu+ model included adsorption sites on the Cu0 and Cu+. The Cu0 and Cu+ interface emerged. The Cu0/Cu+ interface included four adsorption sites: I-top, I-bridge, I-fcc, and I-hcp. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Adsorption of all possible species over different valence Cu catalysts The adsorption energy Eads is deemed as a valid approach to measure the interaction strength between the adsorbate and substrate. Eads is calculated as: (1) Eads(A) = (ECu + EA) – EA/Cu where EA, ECu, and EA/Cu express the energies of the adsorbate, the Cu-based catalyst, and the Cu-based catalyst with adsorbate, respectively. In this section, we considered the adsorptions of the reactants, the possible intermediates, and the products that referred to the reaction of MG synthesis over Cu0, Cu+-perfect, Cu+-defective, and Cu0/Cu+ catalysts. The most stable adsorption configurations of these species are presented in Fig. S1, and the specific adsorption sites and adsorption energies are listed in Table 1 . 3.1.1 DMO and H2 The adsorption of H2 and DMO species at different sites on four types of Cu catalysts were explored, and the most stable adsorption configurations and the corresponding adsorption energies of DMO and H2 species are presented in Fig. S1, Fig. 2 and Table 1, respectively. As one of the adsorption reactants, H2 was optimized to weak adsorption on four kinds of Cu catalysts (Cu+-perfect 31.7 kJ/mol, Cu+-defective 32.5 kJ/mol, Cu0 12.4 kJ/mol [43], and Cu0/Cu+ 10.7 kJ/mol). On the Cu+-perfect catalyst, the calculation results proved that H2 adsorption was a side-on mode, which involved H2 parallel to the surface, and Cucus was the most stabilized adsorption site, which corresponded with previous studies [44,45]. Another interesting feature was that H2 showed dissociative adsorption on the Cu0, Cu+-defective, and Cu0/Cu+ catalysts (Fig. 2). No barrier existed to produce adsorbed H atoms, which was consistent with previous studies [46–48]. As for the DMO molecule, adsorption on Cu+ sites was preferred (perfect 101.3 kJ/mol and defective 90.5 kJ/mol), and the adsorption energy far exceeded that on Cu0 [49] and Cu0/Cu+. The results of the adsorption energies showed that the interaction strength between the DMO molecule and Cu+ catalyst was stronger than that for the Cu0 and Cu0/Cu+ catalysts. Fig. S1 shows that this behavior that DMO molecule adsorption on the surface became stronger, and the formed adsorption configuration was more stable results from the presence of coordination unsaturated copper atoms We predicted that the Cu+ catalyst would display an excellent catalytic performance in DMO dissociation. The charge in absorbed DMO on the Cu+ (perfect and defective) surface was positive by 0.0934e and 0.0849e, respectively, which implied that the DMO molecule can be activated in the Cu+ (perfect and defective) surface, which was consistent with previous results reported by Zhao et al. [50]. Regardless of the Cu+-perfect or Cu+-defective catalyst type, DMO molecules preferred to adsorb on the Cucus site through the O atom, and the Cu–O bond lengths were 1.951 Å and 1.950 Å, respectively. 3.1.2 Possible intermediates and products The most stable adsorption configurations of the possible intermediates and products on the Cu0, Cu+-perfect, Cu+-defective, and Cu0/Cu+ surface are presented in Fig. S1, and the corresponding adsorption sites and adsorption energies are shown in Table 1. As shown in Table 1, different from the H2 species, the interactions between H and Cu catalysts were strengthened, and the adsorption energy of the H on the Cu catalysts with different valences was almost adjacent, which was consistent with previous studies [46,51]. CH3OOCCO and CH3O are deemed to be key reactive intermediates during MG synthesis over Cu catalysts. Compared with the Cu0 [49] or Cu0/Cu+ catalysts, both of them prefer to adsorb on the Cu+-perfect catalyst (CH3OOCCO 200.7 kJ/mol, CH3O 231.1 kJ/mol) (Fig. S1), which illustrated that Cu+ can stabilize CH3OOCCO and CH3O species [4,16,19]. Because of the existence of oxygen vacancies, interactions between the CH3OOCCO, CH3O, and Cu+ surfaces were strengthened (CH3OOCCO 207.5 kJ/mol, CH3O 260.1 kJ/mol). On a Cu+-perfect surface, CH3OOCCO adsorbed at the Cucus site through a C atom, whereas CH3O adsorbed at the Cucus site through an O atom. CH3OOCCO species hydrogenated gradually to form MG. Based on previous studies [52–54], only one approved path exists to describe the formation of MG (Table 2 ). However, according to Table S1, four different intermediates could form during hydrogenation. We wanted to establish the main intermediates and whether the H atom is combined with the C atoms in the terminal CO bond of the acyl species or the O atoms first. We compared the hydrogenation barriers to identify the intermediate species. In the first hydrogenation step, H atoms attacked the C atom at the end of the CH3OOCCO species on the Cu0 and Cu+-perfect catalysts, which required a lower activation energy to generate CH3OOCCHO. Therefore, from an energy perspective, CH3OOCCHO formed more favorably. In the second hydrogenation step, it was more advantageous to form CH3OOCCHOH. CH3OOCCHO and CH3OOCCHOH were the most favorable intermediates during hydrogenation. For the adsorption of key hydrogenation intermediates and possible products over Cu catalysts, compared with the Cu0 and Cu0/Cu+ catalyst, CH3OOCCHO, CH3OOCCHOH, CH3OOCCH2OH, and CH3OH species adsorbed preferentially over the Cu+ catalyst (CH3OOCCHO 88.3 kJ/mol, CH3OOCCHOH 140.4 kJ/mol, CH3OOCCH2OH 107.1 kJ/mol, CH3OH 97.2 kJ/mol), and the adsorption energies became smaller according to the order: Cu+, Cu0/Cu+, Cu0. The above result showed that Cu+ stabilized CH3OOCCHO, CH3OOCCHOH, CH3OOCCH2OH, and CH3OH species. On the Cu+-perfect catalyst, CH3OOCCHO was bound to the Cucus atom through the O atom and the Cu–O bond length was 1.900 Å, whereas CH3OOCCHOH was bound to the Cucus atom through the C atom and the Cu–C bond length is 2.001 Å. CH3OOCCH2OH was bound to the Cucus atom through the O atom and the Cu–O bond length was 1.991 Å. The bound atom changed dynamically during hydrogenation. The charge in MG absorbed on the Cu+-perfect surface was positive by 0.0129e, so the MG molecule could not be activated by Cu+, which indicated that Cu+ may not contribute to further MG transformation. 3.2 Mechanism of DMO hydrogenation to MG The pathway of DMO hydrogenation is shown in Table 2 according to previous studies on the DMO hydrogenation mechanism [52–54]. H2 was dissociated to produce H atoms. DMO was dissociated into methoxy and acyl species. The former was hydrogenated easily to methanol, whereas CH3OOCCO species were combined with H atoms to form MG molecules via CH3OOCCHO and CH3OOCCHOH intermediates. The difference in MG synthesis between the Cu+-perfect, Cu+-defective, Cu0, and Cu0/Cu+ catalysts was studied to reveal the active centers and the roles played in the reaction. A comparison of the rate-determining step of the elementary reactions on four types of Cu catalysts revealed the best Cu catalyst type and the effect of Cu valence on MG formation. The formation of by-product CH3OH and further MG conversion were also considered. The energy barrier Ea and the reaction energy △H were computed from Eqs. (2) and (3). The △H (kJ/mol) and Ea (kJ/mol) of these elementary reactions are shown in Table 3 . (2) Eqs. Ea = ETS - EIS (3) Eqs. △H = EFS - EIS 3.2.1 H2 dissociation Because H atoms that originate from H2 dissociation are indispensable for selective DMO hydrogenation, H2 dissociation was explored initially, and the results are shown in Fig. 2, Fig. S3, Tables 3, and S2. Section 3.1.1 showed that H2 was dissociative adsorption except for Cu+-perfect catalyst and no barrier existed to form adsorbed H atoms. H2 non-dissociative adsorption on a Cu+-defective surface was agreeable at low coverage, whereas dissociative adsorption tended to occur under high coverage conditions [45]. The results indicated that the dissociation barriers of molecular adsorption H2 are 81.0, 299.0, 71.6, and 79.3 kJ/mol with reaction energies of -28.5, -15.1, -40.7, and -21.2 kJ/mol on Cu0, Cu+-perfect, Cu+-defective, and Cu0/Cu+ catalysts, respectively. The dissociation of H2 required that a low energy barrier be overcome, except for the Cu+-perfect catalyst, which was consistent with Mishra’s study [47] (Cu+-deficient 74.75 kJ/mol) and Zhang’s study [46] (Cu+-perfect 260.8 kJ/mol, Cu+-deficient 81.1 kJ/mol). Because of the existence of the oxygen-vacancy, the activation energy was reduced significantly compared with that on the Cu+-perfect catalyst. 3.2.2 DMO dissociation The configurations of initial, transition, and final states are illustrated in Figs. 3a–6 a . The dissociation barriers of the DMO molecule were 140.5, 125.6, 220.2, and 168.6 kJ/mol with reaction energies of 139.8, 11.5, 86.2, and 88.2 kJ/mol on Cu+-perfect, Cu+-defective, Cu0, and Cu0/Cu+ catalysts, respectively. Compared with the Cu0 catalyst, the Cu+ catalyst displayed an excellent performance, namely, CH3OOCCO was formed easily by CO bond cleavage of DMO on the Cu+ sites. Compared with the Cu0 catalyst, the energy barrier was reduced to 168.6 kJ/mol over the Cu0/Cu+ catalyst. The dissociation barrier decreased with Cu+ addition to Cu0. The activation energy was reduced because the Cu+ component was important in DMO dissociation: the DMO molecule could be activated on Cu+ sites, because the charge analysis revealed that the charge of DMO that was adsorbed on the Cu+ catalyst was positive by 0.0934e (perfect) and 0.0849e (defective); and Cu+ sites stabilized the CH3OOCCO and CH3O species, because the adsorption energies of CH3OOCCO and CH3O on Cu+ were higher than Cu0 and Cu0/Cu+. 3.2.3 Hydrogenation stages The configurations of initial, transition, and final states of the CH3OOCCO hydrogenation stages are shown in Figs. 3–6, and the activation energies and reaction energies are listed in Table 3 (R3–R5). 3.2.3.1 CH3OOCCHO formation As shown in Figs. 3b–6 b, for CH3OOCCO hydrogenation to CH3OOCCHO, the optimized coadsorption configuration of H and CH3OOCCO and the most stable adsorption configuration of CH3OOCCHO were chosen to search for the transition state, respectively. On the Cu0 catalyst, CH3OOCCO hydrogenation was used to form CH3OOCCHO via a transition state TS13 with an activation and reaction energy of 60.1 and -39.8 kJ/mol, respectively. According to previous studies, the desorption barrier is close to the absolute value of adsorption energy [24,35,55,56]. Therefore, the absolute value of adsorption energy was used as the desorption energy barrier. The activation energy of CH3OOCCO hydrogenation (60.1 kJ/mol) was much smaller than its adsorption energy (152.0 kJ/mol), which indicates that CH3OOCCO favors hydrogenation rather than desorption on the Cu0 catalyst surface. Similar to the Cu0 catalyst, on Cu+-perfect (99.2 kJ/mol vs 200.7 kJ/mol), Cu+-defective (39.5 kJ/mol vs 207.5 kJ/mol), and Cu0/Cu+ catalysts (141.5 kJ/mol vs 155.3 kJ/mol), CH3OOCCO hydrogenation was preferred. 3.2.3.2 CH3OOCCHOH formation For the second hydrogenation step (Figs. 3c–6 c), on the Cu0 and Cu+-perfect catalyst surface, CH3OOCCHO hydrogenation was more favorable than its desorption (Cu0 23.7 kJ/mol vs 48.0 kJ/mol, Cu+-perfect 68.2 kJ/mol vs 88.3 kJ/mol). In contrast, on the surface of Cu+-defective and Cu0/Cu+, CH3OOCCHOH tended to desorb (Cu+-defective 143.1 kJ/mol vs 116.9 kJ/mol, Cu0/Cu+ 118.5 kJ/mol vs 50.2 kJ/mol). 3.2.3.3 MG formation Starting from the CH3OOCCHOH intermediate, CH3OOCCHOH hydrogenation to CH3OOCCH2OH via TS15 needed an activation and reaction energy of 91.5 kJ/mol and –73.3 kJ/mol, respectively, on the Cu0 catalyst. The activation energy of CH3OOCCHOH hydrogenation to MG was lower than its adsorption energy, which suggested that CH3OOCCHOH hydrogenation proceeded without CH3OOCCHOH desorption (Cu0 91.5 kJ/mol vs 101.5 kJ/mol). CH3OOCCHOH was hydrogenated easily to form MG only on Cu0 catalyst, followed by its desorption to form MG. In comparison, it was not hydrogenated easily on the other three kinds of Cu catalysts (Figs. 3d–6 d). 3.2.4 Side reactions By-product CH3OH was produced preferentially on the Cu+-perfect catalyst and is most thermodynamically favorable compared with the other three catalysts (Cu+-perfect Ea: 6.7 kJ/mol, ΔH: -53.1 kJ/mol) (Fig. S2). MG dissociates with difficulty on the four types of Cu catalysts, which suggests that MG is a stable product (Fig. S2). 3.3 General discussion 3.3.1 Potential energy surface (PES) and reaction mechanism The potential-energy surface (PES) for the complete MG synthesis from DMO hydrogenation on Cu catalysts is depicted in Fig. 7 . The potential energy of the hydrogenation on Cu0/Cu+ was lower than that on the Cu0 and Cu+-perfect. However, the potential energy on Cu+-defective was lower that on Cu0/Cu+, which suggested that it was the most thermodynamically favorable process [57]. A contrast of the energy barrier of the rate-determining step on Cu0/Cu+ with that on Cu0, Cu+-perfect, and Cu+-defective is presented in Fig. 8 . For the Cu0 catalyst, the rate-determining step was DMO dissociation, whereas H2 dissociation became the rate-determining step on the Cu+-perfect catalyst. For the Cu0/Cu+ catalyst, the rate-determining step was the same as that on the Cu0 catalyst. On the Cu+-defective catalyst, the third hydrogenation step was the rate-determining step. In the overall MG synthesis from DMO hydrogenation, the energy barriers of the rate-determining steps were 168.6 kJ/mol, 207.5 kJ/mol, 220.2 kJ/mol, and 299.0 kJ/mol on Cu0/Cu+, Cu+-defective, Cu0, and Cu+-perfect catalysts, respectively. On the Cu0/Cu+ catalyst, the energy barrier was decreased markedly compared with the rate-determining steps on single Cu0 catalyst or Cu+ catalyst (168.6 kJ/mol vs 220.2 kJ/mol vs 299.0 kJ/mol), which indicated that the Cu+ component that was doped in the Cu0 catalyst was important. A comparison showed that the reaction steps were more favorable kinetically and thermodynamically on Cu0/Cu+ than the other three Cu catalysts. The calculated results demonstrated that although H2 was formed by dissociation adsorption on the Cu+-defective catalyst, Cu0 was primarily responsible for the dissociation of H2, whereas Cu+ contributed to DMO dissociation. During hydrogenation, Cu0 exhibited an excellent catalytic performance. The Cu+ sites stabilized the intermediates. The formation of oxygen vacancies strengthened the adsorption energy of the radical intermediates with Cu+ sites, except for molecules of DMO, MG, and CH3OH. 3.3.2 Analysis of differential charge density and Hirschfeld charge Differential charge density was calculated to probe the role of Cu species. In Fig. 9 , the blue area showed that electron density was increased, whereas the yellow area suggested that the electron density is reduced. The electron exchange of H2 on the surface of Cu0 exceeded that of Cu+, which was assigned mainly to the enhancement of electron-donating capability of the surface Cu atom. For the Cu+ catalyst, the Cu atom donated electrons to H to form Cu-H bonds. In contrast, H2 was adsorbed on Cu0 with four Cu-donated electrons to H. Similarly, compared with the Cu0 catalyst, the Cu atom on the Cu+ surface donated more electrons to the DMO molecule, which generated an intense interaction, and formed stable chemical bonds. Then, the calculation of the Hirshfeld charge (Table 1) was carried out. The transfer of electrons between Cu0 and H2 far exceeded that between Cu+-perfect and H2 (–0.2246e vs 0.0329e). The result for DMO was opposite compared with the H2 (0.0934e vs –0.0194e) Therefore, the calculation of differential charge density and Hirschfeld charge indicated that H2 can be activated by Cu0, whereas DMO can be activated by Cu+. 3.3.3 Presentation of descriptor and d-Partial density of states analysis Similar to the hydrogenation of C2H4 to C2H6 on the WOx surface [23], on Cu0 and Cu0/Cu+ surfaces, DMO dissociation was the rate-determining step, whereas on Cu+ perfect and defective surfaces, the rate-determining steps were H2 dissociation and CH3OOCCHOH hydrogenation, respectively. Remarkably, the activity changes with the valence state from Cu0 to Cu+. However, because Cu+-perfect and Cu+-defective both belong to the category of Cu+, the performance of the Cu+-perfect and Cu+-defective catalysts is similar during the entire hydrogenation process. In consequence, we chose Cu+-perfect to reveal the rule of the activity change with the valence state. During MG formation, the energy barrier for H2 dissociation depended on the adsorption of H2 and 2H, and the energy barrier for DMO dissociation depended on the adsorption of DMO and CH3OOCCO + CH3O, and the energy barrier for the combining of CH3OOCCHOH with H was determined by the adsorption of CH3OOCCHOH+H and CH3OOCCH2OH. Five linear connections of adsorption energies of CH3OOCCO+H with 2H, DMO, CH3OOCCO + CH3O, CH3OOCCHOH+H, and CH3OOCCH2OH were observed, as shown in Fig. 10 a. The adsorption energies of 2H, DMO, CH3OOCCO + CH3O, CH3OOCCHOH+H, and CH3OOCCH2OH increased linearly with an increase in CH3OOCCO+H adsorption energy on Cu0, Cu0/Cu+, and Cu+ surfaces. The growth rate of adsorption energies (DMO, CH3OOCCO + CH3O, CH3OOCCHOH+H, and CH3OOCCH2OH) was close. The correlation coefficient between the adsorption energies of species (2H, DMO, CH3OOCCO + CH3O, CH3OOCCHOH+H, and CH3OOCCH2OH) and CH3OOCCO+H was close to 0.99 because there was an inherent rule in the adsorption of species on the surface of copper with different valence states. Consequently, similar to what was proposed previously by Chang [20], the energy barrier of the rate-limiting step can be estimated by using the adsorption of CH3OOCCO+H as a “descriptor”. The histogram of Ea versus CH3OOCCO+H adsorption energy in Fig. 10b displays a trend of decreasing first and then increasing from Cu(0) to Cu(I), and the adsorption energy of CH3OOCCO+H is at around 402 kJ·mol−1, which exhibited the best catalytic performance. We describe why the activity changed with the valence state from Cu0 to Cu+ and why Cu0 and Cu+ were poor hydrogenation catalysts. Strong interactions between 2H and the catalyst (501.0 kJ·mol−1) (strong CH3OOCCO+H adsorption: 481.2 kJ·mol−1) implied that the hydrogenation reaction occurred with difficulty, which indicated that the catalyst can be poisoned easily, such as for the Cu+-perfect catalyst (Cu+-perfect 501.0 kJ·mol−1, Cu0/Cu+-perfect 43.6 kJ·mol−1, Cu0 13.3 kJ·mol−1). In contrast, weak interactions between the DMO and catalyst (46.0 kJ·mol−1) (weak CH3OOCCO+H adsorption: 394.4 kJ·mol−1) suggested that DMO was difficult to dissociate, such as for the Cu0 catalyst. Cu0 exhibited the best hydrogenation activity (91.5 kJ·mol-1 vs 244.0 kJ·mol−1) because the adsorption energy of CH3OOCCHOH+H was moderate (Cu0 363.8 kJ·mol−1, Cu0/Cu+ 373.9 kJ·mol−1, Cu+-perfect 416.0 kJ·mol−1). In general, the Cu catalyst performance toward MG formation correlated with the adsorption energy of CH3OOCCO+H. When the adsorption energy of CH3OOCCO+H was located in a moderate degree, H2 dissociation, DMO dissociation and hydrogenation could proceed easily and showed the best catalytic performance. At a deep level, the surface geometry and electron supply capability of the surface Cu atom on the Cu catalyst surface determined the CH3OOCCO+H adsorption state and its CH3OOCCO+H adsorption intensity, which affected the catalytic performance [58]. Accordingly, to assess the adsorption activity of Cu0, Cu0/Cu+, and Cu+, the d-band center was calculated to be -2.44, -2.33, and -1.40 eV for Cu on Cu0, Cu0/Cu+, and Cu+, respectively (Fig. 11 ). When the composition changes from Cu0 to Cu+, the upward shift of the d-band center of Cu explained the stronger adsorption of CH3OOCCO+H at the Cu sites. As a result, when the d-band center of Cu atom is located in the medium position (-2.33 eV,) CH3OOCCO+H adsorption energy is 402 kJ·mol−1, and Cu0/Cu+ catalyst exhibits the best catalytic activity toward MG formation, which consistent with previous study [24,59]. 4 Conclusions This work demonstrated that the Cu0/Cu+ complex catalyst was an optimal catalyst in DMO hydrogenation to MG, which coordinated the valence effects, eliminated the adverse effects, and improved the catalytic performance significantly compared with the individual component. The remarkable efficiency of the catalysts was attributed to the synergistic effects between Cu0 and Cu+ sites. We revealed contributions by Cu0 and Cu+ sites in the reaction. Cu0 was beneficial to H2 dissociation and was primarily responsible for hydrogenation (CH3OOCCO-MG), whereas Cu+ was beneficial to DMO dissociation. Cu+ could stabilize intermediates. Five linear connections of adsorption energies of CH3OOCCO+H with 2H, DMO, CH3OOCCO + CH3O, CH3OOCCHOH+H, and CH3OOCCH2OH were fitted; hence, the catalytic performance could be judged by using the CH3OOCCO+H adsorption energy as the descriptor. Because the adsorption energy of CH3OOCCO+H was located to a moderate degree on Cu0/Cu+, Cu0/Cu+ presented the best catalytic performance. We offered a framework for the scientific design of Cu catalysts for DMO hydrogenation to MG. Our results may provide a theoretical direction for the hydrogenation of other carbonyl groups. coredata.dc:description: The development of high-performance copper (Cu)-based catalysts is critical to achieve the industrial hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to methyl glycolate (MG). To understand the effect of Cu valence state on MG formation, a theoretical study was performed over Cu+-perfect, Cu+-defective, Cu0, and Cu0/Cu+ catalysts by density-functional theory calculations. Calculations showed that the rate-limiting step (RLS) on the Cu+-perfect catalyst was H2 dissociation, whereas CH3OOCCHOH hydrogenation becomes the RLS for the Cu+-defective catalyst. For Cu0 and Cu0/Cu+, DMO dissociation was the RLS. Compared with other three catalysts, Cu0/Cu+ bicomponent catalyst needed to overcome the lowest barrier (168.6 kJ/mol), which is suggested to be an optimal catalyst for selective DMO hydrogenation. The remarkable catalyst efficiency was ascribed to the synergistic effect between the Cu0 and Cu+ sites. The calculation results indicated that Cu0 was beneficial to the dissociation of H2 and was primarily responsible for the hydrogenation (CH3OOCCO-MG), whereas Cu+ was beneficial to DMO dissociation. Besides, Cu+ stabilized intermediates. In summary, we have found that the adsorption energy of CH3OOCCO+H can be considered as the catalyst performance descriptor through the calculation results. Because Cu0/Cu+ agreed with the index of moderate adsorption energy, Cu0/Cu+ presented the best catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Density-functional theory study on hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate to methyl glycolate over copper catalyst: Effect of copper valence state
